WRITING.TITLE: CMV: We should start teaching British spelling and grammar as the default way write and type in the English language.
WRITING.TEXT:
The English language is being taught in schools all over the globe in English and non English speaking countries. However, from my experiences in being taught English in school, it can become confusing and frankly frustrating when you read different spellings for the same words, (colour and color and plow and plough to name a few).
I can imagine that someone who isn't fluent in the English language can easily be mistaken that these words mean completely different things, or when someone has seen the word colour, but hasn't seen the word plough. This would most likely cause the person to write sentences like "The colour of the plow was red". And in my opinion, consistency is the most important part when writing English.
So why do I believe that British spelling should be the norm?
British spelling is the most widely adopted form of English grammar. Many people see it as "oh the Brits say lef-tenn-ant-", while it's really a case of, "The English speaking world except for the US says lef-tenn-ant". Since British grammar is the most adopted and officially recognized in words such as aluminium vs aluminum and pronunciations such as bai-san-taines vs byh-zan-teens. Most historians see them as the bai-san-taines and most scientists see aluminium cans.
So why should I care?
Well, for the confusing factor as mentioned above and due to the fact that Google will auto correct or redline British spelling.
To summarize, we should start teaching British spelling in schools and make it into the grammatical norm of the English language. That way, we can avoid confusion and inconsistencies when we write and type. I'm NOT however, arguing for British pronunciation. That should be entirely up to the individual.
